rev.diff:
Line 522: Line 522:
On February 13, an article in the state-controlled newspaper, [[Al-Ahram]], questioned the inclinations of [[Google|Google Inc.]] and its executive and activist, [[Wael Ghonim|Wael Ghoneim]], due to certain translation errors when using the Google Translate engine that were perceived as dubious by some.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gate.ahram.org.eg/News/39710.aspx|title=Al-Ahram: Google translation sparks disappointment at Wael Ghoneim|author=Sara Ne'mat-Allah|date=February 13, 2011|publisher-Al-Ahram}}</ref> One reported error was translating any fictitious phrase along the lines of "... occupies Israel" in Arabic into "Israel occupies..." in English. [[Google Translate]] is a [[Statistical machine translation|statistical translation engine]] that [[Google Translate#Translation mistakes and oddities|uses web search statistics rather than grammatical rules to yield a probable translation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0809/technology-computer-learning-google-translate.html|title=Forbes: Google Translate tangles with computer learning|author=Lee Gomes|date=July 22, 2010|publisher-Forbes}}</ref> Since "...occupies Israel" is a low-probability query owing to the fact that Israel has not been occupied and "Israel occupies..." is a higher-probability query on the other hand, the limitation of statistical translation results in the inaccurate translation.
On February 13, an article in the state-controlled newspaper, [[Al-Ahram]], questioned the inclinations of [[Google|Google Inc.]] and its executive and activist, [[Wael Ghonim|Wael Ghoneim]], due to certain translation errors when using the Google Translate engine that were perceived as dubious by some.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gate.ahram.org.eg/News/39710.aspx|title=Al-Ahram: Google translation sparks disappointment at Wael Ghoneim|author=Sara Ne'mat-Allah|date=February 13, 2011|publisher-Al-Ahram}}</ref> One reported error was translating any fictitious phrase along the lines of "... occupies Israel" in Arabic into "Israel occupies..." in English. [[Google Translate]] is a [[Statistical machine translation|statistical translation engine]] that [[Google Translate#Translation mistakes and oddities|uses web search statistics rather than grammatical rules to yield a probable translation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0809/technology-computer-learning-google-translate.html|title=Forbes: Google Translate tangles with computer learning|author=Lee Gomes|date=July 22, 2010|publisher-Forbes}}</ref> Since "...occupies Israel" is a low-probability query owing to the fact that Israel has not been occupied and "Israel occupies..." is a higher-probability query on the other hand, the limitation of statistical translation results in the inaccurate translation.
